text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 13.1.7, Taxpayer Advocate Case Processing, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria.
IRM 13.1.7.1 added new section Program Scope and Objectives.
IRM 13.1.7.4 incorporated IPU 21U0932, issued 07-13-2021, updated to include streamline exceptions to limitations on Taxpayer Advocate Service case criteria and renumbered.

IRM 13.1.7.4(6) incorporated IPU 21U0728, issued 05-13-2021, updated to include cases involving the exclusion of unemployment compensation received in taxable year 2020 from gross income as an exception to TAS case criteria per IGM TAS-13-0521-0006, Interim Guidance on Exceptions to TAS Case Acceptance Criteria For Taxpayer Issues Related to Unemployment Compensation Received in Taxable Year 2020.
IRM 13.1.7.4(4) incorporated IPU 21U0454, issued 03-23-2021, updated to include ERS Status 100 as an exception to TAS case acceptance.
IRM 13.1.7.4(4) incorporated IPU 21U0394, issued 03-12-2021, updated to clarify TAS case acceptance criteria on ERS cases.

IRM 13.1.7.4(9) incorporated IPU 21U0149, issued 01-26-2021, updated to add TAS case acceptance criteria exceptions per IGM TAS 13-0121-0003, Interim Guidance on Exceptions to TAS Case Acceptance Criteria Taxpayer Issues Solely Related to the Processing of Original and Amended Returns with No Indication of IRS Receipt of the Return.

IRM 13.1.7.4(5) incorporated IPU 21U0149, issued 01-26-2021, updated to add TAS case acceptance criteria exceptions per IGM TAS 13-0121-0001, Interim Guidance on Exclusion from TAS Case Acceptance Criteria Taxpayers Impacted by Pre-Refund Wage Veriﬁcation Hold and Amended
IRM 13.1.7.4(1) incorporated IPU 20U0345, issued 03-20-2020, added change to case acceptance criteria for Pre-Refund Wage Veriﬁcation Hold and Amended Returns.
IRM 13.1.7.5(2) incorporated IPU 21U0044, issued 01-05-2021, updated to add note to include case acceptance to EIP refund tracers.
IRM 13.1.7.5 incorporated IPU 20U1268, issued 11-24-2020, updated EIP TAS case acceptance criteria per IGM TAS-13-1120-0018, Interim Guidance - Economic Impact Payments.
IRM 13.1.7.5 incorporated IPU 20U0945, issued 08-26-2020, added new content listing case acceptance criteria for Economic Impact Payment issues.
IRM 13.1.7.6 incorporated IPU 20U0945, issued 08-26-2020, new subsection, content moved from IRM 13.1.7.5.
Exhibit 13.1.7-1 Updated processing times for various issues due to IRM changes.
Exhibit 13.1.7-4 Case Criteria Crosswalk to 7811 and Regulations added new exhibit.
Minor editorial, grammar, and punctuation changes and updated IRM references.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 13.1.7, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures dated February 5, 2016, superseded. The following IRM Procedural Updates (IPUs) issued from March 2, 2020 through March 23, 2021 have been incorporated into this IRM 20U0345, 20U0671, 20U0945, 20U1268, 21U0044, 21U0100, 21U0149, 21U0394 and 21U0454.
AUDIENCE
Primarily Taxpayer Advocate Service Employees.
Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support

) Scope and (

) Purpose: This IRM discusses information to consider in determining when taxpayer meets TAS case criteria to be referred to TAS for resolution and assist in determining case criteria based on statutory and regulatory authority. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees when determining when a taxpayer would qualify for TAS assistance. (
) Policy Owner: The National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA). (
) Program Owner: The Director, Technical Analysis and Guidance, who reports to (EDCA-ITS).
) Background (

) TAS has identiﬁed criteria that qualify taxpayers for TAS assistance, which includes an independent review by a TAS employee of actions that have taken or need to be taken to resolve the problems taxpayers are experiencing. TAS Criteria
reﬂect situations requiring acceptance of taxpayer cases worked by TAS. TAS commonly refers to Criteria
as “Economic Burden” cases, Criteria
as “Systemic Burden” cases, Criteria
as “Best Interest the Taxpayer” and Criteria
as “Public Policy.”
) Responsibilities (
) IRS employees working individual taxpayer issues are responsible for deter- mining when a taxpayer’s issue meets criterion for referral to TAS. (

) TAS employees are responsible for making case acceptance determinations and will take appropriate actions to move a taxpayer’s issue to resolution taking the taxpayer’s best interests into consideration based on the procedures in this IRM section.
) Pursuant to IRC
(c), the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate (known as Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS)) shall assist taxpayers to resolve problems with the IRS.
) Reports (

) Reports to monitor the quality of TAS cases are derived from TAMIS and TAS Case Quality Review System (CQRS). Monthly, quarterly, and ﬁscal cumulative reports as well as drill down reports are available for data analysis.
) Exhibit
contains a list of terms and their deﬁnitions used throughout this IRM.
) Exhibit
contains a list of acronyms and their deﬁnitions used through- out this IRM. (
) Resources (
) All related IRM resources are listed in Exhibit
, General Response Time Guidelines. (
) Exhibit
contains a Crosswalk which matches Case Criteria to IRC
and Treas. Reg.

IRS employees working individual taxpayer issues are responsible for deter- mining when a taxpayer’s issue meets criterion for referral to TAS.
13.1 Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures
to TAS Criteria (
) Under IRC
)(C)(ii), the National Taxpayer Advocate has developed case criteria for referring taxpayers to TAS. Those criteria are Criteria
are explained in greater detail in this chapter. The case criteria is based in on IRC

and the corresponding Treasury Regulation dealing with the cumstances in which TAS may issue a Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO). Although case criteria and signiﬁcant hardship for purposes of a TAO are always the same, they are nonetheless very closely aligned. A detailed crosswalk is in Exhibit
Keep in mind that TAS’s ability to assist taxpayers is much broader than the circumstances which qualify for a TAO. (

) TAS Case Criteria should not be viewed as a means of excluding taxpayers from TAS, but rather, as a guide to TAS case acceptance. The criteria under which TAS accepts a case should not govern whether a taxpayer is entitled relief. Similarly, as discussed in IRM
, TAS Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO), the criteria under which TAS accepts a case does not govern whether TAS can issue a TAO. (

) Taxpayers do not need to validate their hardship to be accepted into the TAS program. TAS employees may need to document the hardship in the course developing the case and determining what relief is appropriate. Criteria (

) As an independent organization within the IRS, TAS helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS and recommends changes to prevent future problems. TAS fulﬁlls its statutory mission by working with taxpayers to resolve problems with the IRS. TAS case acceptance criteria fall into four main categories: (

) Economic Burden - Economic burden cases are those involving a ﬁnancial difficulty to the taxpayer: an IRS action or inaction has caused or will cause negative ﬁnancial consequences or have a long-term adverse impact on the taxpayer. • Criteria
: The taxpayer is experiencing economic harm or is about suffer economic harm. • Criteria
: The taxpayer is facing an immediate threat of adverse action. • Criteria
: The taxpayer will incur signiﬁcant costs if relief is not (including fees for professional representation). • Criteria
: The taxpayer will suffer irreparable injury or long-term adverse impact if relief is not granted. (

) Systemic Burden - Systemic burden cases are those in which an IRS process, system, or procedure has failed to operate as intended, and as a result the IRS has failed to timely respond to or resolve a taxpayer’s issue. • Criteria
: The taxpayer has experienced a delay of more than
to resolve a tax account problem. • Criteria
: The taxpayer has not received a response or resolution the problem or inquiry by the date promised. • Criteria
: A system or procedure has either failed to operate as intended, or failed to resolve the taxpayer’s problem or dispute within the IRS.
Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
K (
Criteria 7: A system or procedure has either failed to operate as intended, or failed to resolve the taxpayer’s problem or dispute within
Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria 13.1.7
Best Interest of the Taxpayer - TAS acceptance of these cases will help ensure that taxpayers receive fair and equitable treatment and that their rights as taxpayers are protected.
Criteria 9: The National Taxpayer Advocate determines compelling public policy warrants assistance to an individual or group of taxpayers.
) Criteria
– Per IRC
)(B) and Treas. Reg.

, the taxpayer is experiencing economic harm or is about to suffer economic harm. The economic harm may be the result of actions by the IRS or created because of circumstances in the taxpayer’s personal life.

IRC 7811(a)(2)(A), (C), and (D) outline three examples of signiﬁcant hardship that are categorized below as Case Criteria 2, 3 and 4. Economic harm situations that require TAS’s assistance but do not fall under these criteria will be captured under Case Criteria 1.
Example: A taxpayer’s return has been selected for examination based on the claim for Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). The taxpayer is expecting a $

refund but cannot wait for the completion of the examination, as the taxpayer has a serious medical condition and no health insurance. She needs the money to pay for prescription drugs and nonelective surgery. This case should be accepted into the TAS program as a Criteria
case.
) Criteria
-- Per IRC
)(A) and Treas. Reg.

)(ii)(A), the taxpayer is facing an immediate threat of adverse action. Most situations will involve an action by the IRS, such as ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien, serving a Notice of Levy, or seizing property. Threat of adverse actions can also involve the taxpayer’s personal situations, such as utility cutoffs or evictions. Such actions may result in negative ﬁnancial consequences or economic burden to the taxpayer. A warning of impending action that will negatively impact the taxpayer is considered a “threat”. An immediate threat is deﬁned as an action that will take place in the very near future.

Example: On June 15, the taxpayer came to TAS with an eviction notice stating that he will be evicted on July 1 if his rent is not paid. The taxpayer is awaiting a refund of $2,000 on his Form 1040 income tax return. This refund will pay in full his arrearage, thus preventing the eviction. This
Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures
case would be accepted into the TAS program as a Criteria 2 case because the threat of adverse action exists (the eviction notice), and the threat is immediate (15 days).
) Criteria
-- Per IRC
)(C) and Treas. Reg.

)(ii)(C), the taxpayer will incur signiﬁcant costs if relief is not granted (including fees for professional representation). Situations where the IRS is unable to immediately make adjustments, process returns, release a lien, etc., could result in the taxpayer having to incur signiﬁcant costs. Signiﬁcant costs could include pro- fessional fees for representation.

(3) Criteria 3 -- Per IRC 7811(a)(2)(C) and Treas. Reg. 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii)(C), the taxpayer will incur signiﬁcant costs if relief is not granted (including fees for professional representation). Situations where the IRS is unable to immediately make adjustments, process returns, release a lien, etc., could result in the taxpayer having to incur signiﬁcant costs. Signiﬁcant costs could include pro- fessional fees for representation.
Note: The Local Taxpayer Advocate (LTA) will determine what constitutes signiﬁ- cant costs based on the facts and circumstances of each case.

Example: The IRS sends a corporation a notice requesting payment of an out- standing balance of employment taxes and penalties owed by the business. The notice indicates that the business has employment tax balances with respect to
employment tax quarters totaling $

The business provides documentation to the IRS, which contends that if all payments were correctly applied to each quarter, there would be no balance due. The IRS requests additional records and documentation. Because there are
quarters involved, to comply with this request the business asserts that it will need to hire an accountant, who estimates he will charge at least $
to organize all the records and provide a detailed analysis of how to apply the deposits and payments. The business is facing signiﬁcant costs.

to organize all the records and provide detailed analysis of how to apply the deposits and payments. The business is facing signiﬁcant costs. (

-- IRC
)(D) and Treas. Reg.

)(ii)(D), the taxpayer will suffer irreparable injury or long-term adverse impact if relief is granted. This includes situations where a taxpayer may lose assets, income, potential income if relief is not provided. Some situations include loss of the ability to be licensed or bonded as part of the taxpayer’s occupation, or loss borrowing power or clients due to ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien. Other situations may involve damage to credit ratings resulting in denial of a loan. Example: The taxpayer has a lien on his property due to an outstanding tax liability. He is trying to reﬁnance his mortgage, which would result in a lower monthly payment and would allow him to pay his outstanding tax liability. He has ﬁled an amended return which would eliminate the tax liability. The amended return has been selected for examination, but action has been taken. This case should be accepted into the TAS program as a Criteria
case. Criteria

Other situations may involve damage to credit ratings resulting in denial of a loan.

Example: The taxpayer has a lien on his property due to an outstanding tax liability. He is trying to reﬁnance his mortgage, which would result in a lower monthly payment and would allow him to pay his outstanding tax liability. He has ﬁled an amended return which would eliminate the tax liability. The amended return has been selected for examination, but no action has been taken. This case should be accepted into the TAS program as a Criteria
case.

is met when the problem or inquiry is delayed more than
days beyond the normal response time for the particular action . Refer to Exhibit

Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria 13.1.7 page

Example: A taxpayer ﬁles an individual income tax return with a Schedule C claiming business expenses. The taxpayer received a notice ten months ago that the return was selected for examination and provided the requested documentation. The taxpayer has received no further contact from the IRS which is a delay of more than
days beyond normal response time.
Example: A taxpayer received an examination determination from a revenue agent. On January
, the taxpayer wrote to the IRS, requesting an interest calculation so she could pay her account in full. On March
, the taxpayer contacts TAS for the interest calculation because she has not received a response to her letter. Since more than
days have passed from January
, Criteria
is met.
Criteria

is met when the IRS sends multiple interim responses and no other actions by the IRS have been taken. Interim letters can extend pre- scribed time frames unless the delay is extensive or unreasonable. Judgment should be used to determine if the operating division or func- tion’s delay is justiﬁed or whether it is an unwarranted delay.

scribed time frames unless the delay is extensive or unreasonable. Judgment should be used to determine if the operating division or func- tion’s delay is justiﬁed or whether it is an unwarranted delay. Example: A taxpayer writes to the IRS for an abatement of his federal tax deposit penalty on June
The taxpayer receives a response from the IRS on July
, acknowledging receipt of his letter and informing him that it will be another
days before his inquiry can be answered. On July

, the taxpayer receives another IRS letter stating that it will take an additional eight weeks for a reply. The TAS employee checks IDRS information and no action has been taken by the IRS on the taxpayer’s account other than sending the second interim correspondence. The taxpayer’s circumstances meet Criteria
d. Delays due to taxpayer unresponsiveness will not meet Criteria
Example: A taxpayer writes to the IRS for an abatement of his federal tax deposit penalty on June
The taxpayer receives a response from the IRS on July
, acknowledging receipt of his letter and requesting additional information by July
to abate the penalty. On July
, the taxpayer receives another IRS letter with a second request for information. The taxpayer has not submitted any information for consideration. The taxpayer contacts TAS for assistance on August

, stating the penalty has not been abated. The TAS employee checks IDRS and determines from the history items that multiple requests for in- formation were sent to the taxpayer. The TAS employee asks if the taxpayer has received any contact from the IRS. The taxpayer states he did receive a request for more information but has not mailed it in. This circumstance does not meet Criteria
However, TAS should still explain to the taxpayer what information the IRS, in general, needs to make a penalty abatement.

The taxpayer’s circumstances meet Criteria
Example: A taxpayer writes to the IRS for an abatement of his federal tax deposit penalty on June
The taxpayer receives a response from the IRS on July

to abate the penalty. On July

The TAS employee asks if the taxpayer has received any contact from the IRS. The taxpayer states he did receive a request for more information but has not mailed it in. This circumstance does not meet Criteria
However, TAS should still explain to the taxpayer what information the IRS, in general, needs to make a penalty abatement.

)(ii), the taxpayer has not received a response or resolution to the problem or inquiry the date promised. Example: The taxpayer has been in contact with the Correspondence Examination unit at an IRS campus because of alleged unreported income. The tax examiner requested substantiation of the taxpayer’s basis of some stock transactions. The taxpayer sent the information ﬁve weeks ago. The taxpayer received IRS correspondence acknowledging receipt of the in- formation. The IRS correspondence also indicated that a determination would be made and the taxpayer would be contacted by March
On March
, the taxpayer contacts the NTA toll-free number for assistance. The inquiry is accepted into TAS as a Criteria
case because the taxpayer was not contacted by the promised date of March
) Criteria
-- Per IRC
)(B) and Treas. Reg.

)(ii), a system or procedure has either failed to operate as intended or failed to resolve the taxpayer’s problem or dispute within the IRS. a. When a taxpayer speciﬁcally requests TAS assistance and no other case criteria is met, accept the case under Case Criteria

These cases meet TAS criteria because the taxpayer’s hesitance or unwillingness to work within the IRS structure to resolve his or her problem is an indication of systemic failure. Document the conversation in the TAMIS history. b. The following are examples of when an inquiry meets criteria

: Example: The IRS examined a taxpayer’s return in a prior year for EITC and sub- sequently allowed the credit. The taxpayer ﬁled her subsequent year return and the IRS failed to issue her refund. The taxpayer contacts TAS for assistance. TAS determines the refund was held because the IDRS transaction code
indicator was never reversed, as it should have been. The taxpayer’s circumstances meet Criteria

because the IRS’s procedures for releasing a refund freeze failed to operate as intended. Example: A taxpayer writes to the IRS for an abatement of his federal tax deposit penalty and requests a credit elect to the next quarter. The IRS abates the penalty, but the overpayment has not been credited to the next quarter. The taxpayer’s circumstances meet Criteria
because the IRS’s procedures for crediting overpayments failed to operate as intended.

Example: The taxpayer has been in contact with the Correspondence Examination unit at an IRS campus because of alleged unreported income. The tax examiner requested substantiation of the taxpayer’s basis of some stock transactions. The taxpayer sent the information ﬁve weeks ago. The taxpayer received IRS correspondence acknowledging receipt of the in- formation. The IRS correspondence also indicated that a determination would be made and the taxpayer would be contacted by March

case because the taxpayer was not contacted by the promised date of March

Section
Procedures. (
) Looking at the signiﬁcant hardship requirement in IRC
may be useful in making a Criteria
determination. Section

provides “the National Taxpayer Advocate may issue a Taxpayer Assistance Order if the National Taxpayer Advocate determines the taxpayer is suffering or about to suffer a signiﬁcant hardship as a result of the manner in which the internal revenue laws are being administered by the Secretary. “ Treas. Reg.

), further explains that signiﬁcant hardship means “a serious privation is caused or about to be caused to the taxpayer as the result of the particular manner which the revenue laws are being administered by the IRS.” Thus, if a taxpayer is experiencing or about to experience a serious privation of taxpayer rights, then the case meets Criteria
In considering whether a taxpayer is experiencing or about to experience a serious privation of taxpayer rights, consider whether any of the taxpayer’s rights have been impaired. See IRM
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR).Ifanyof these rights have been impaired and no other case criteria ﬁts, it would be appropriate to accept the case under Criteria
If no rights have been impaired, next consider the equities. If the action the IRS is taking is equitable, a case can also be classiﬁed as Criteria

Criteria

)(B) and Treas. Reg.

)(ii), the NTA determines compelling public policy warrants assistance to an individual or group of taxpayers. The NTA has the sole authority for determining which issues are included in this criterion and will so designate by memo.

Example: The NTA determined inquiries related to organizations where the IRS automatically revoked their tax-exempt status because the organization did not ﬁle an annual return or notice for three consecutive years met this criteria.
Note: Criteria 9 should only be used when the taxpayer’s case does not ﬁt within any other criteria.
13.1 Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures
There are certain cases that should not be accepted into TAS:
The focus of the taxpayer’s inquiry solely involves frivolous tax strategies intended to avoid or delay the ﬁling or paying of federal taxes:

If the Inquiry Then Is received from a Congressional Office where the taxpayer’s refund has been stopped by a Refund Integrity Veriﬁcation Operation (RIVO) ﬁlter beginning March 5, 2021. TAS will accept the case. These cases will be coded in TAMIS as Criteria 9 even if they may also qualify under Criteria 1 through 8. Involves an Offset Bypass Refund (OBR). TAS will accept the case. See IRM 13.1.24.6.2, Advocating for Taxpayers Seeking Offset Bypass Refunds. Involves returns for prior tax years ( i.e ., for tax years before 2020) if the return was ﬁled before the current ﬁling season. In these situations, the return would be held over from prior year’s processing refund freezes. TAS will accept the case. Note: If the prior year return was recently ﬁled (after January 1, 2021) the limi- tations on case acceptance will apply.
would be held over from prior year’s processing refund freezes. tations on case acceptance will apply. (
) IRS and TAS will refer taxpayer meeting TAS criteria
(systemic burden) who seek assistance with an identity theft issue to the Accounts Management Identity Protection Specialized Unit (IPSU). See IRM
, Identity Theft Assistance Request (ITAR) - General Information, and IRM
, IPSU Referral Procedures: (
) TAS will generally not accept the following types of inquires involving the Pro- cessing of Original Returns (Issue Code (IC)
, Unpostable/Rejected Returns (IC
), Processing of Amended Returns (IC
), and Injured Spouse Claims (IC
) that fall within Systemic Burden Criteria

: a. In these four categories of cases, processing delays typically arise either because the affected functions are overloaded with work or because of systemic processing glitches. Assuming these processing delays do not create an economic burden, TAS’s role is typically limited to issuing an Operations Assistance Request (OAR) to the appropriate function to advocate for resolution of the taxpayer’s problem, providing updates to taxpayers, and looking for patterns of delay to identify systemic problems.

In these four categories of cases, processing delays typically arise either because the affected functions are overloaded with work or because of systemic processing glitches. Assuming these processing delays do not create an economic burden, TAS’s role is typically limited to issuing an Operations Assistance Request (OAR) to the appropriate function to advocate for resolution of the taxpayer’s problem, providing updates to taxpayers, and looking for patterns of delay to identify systemic problems.
Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria 13.1.7 page

There are two notable exceptions under which TAS will continue to accept Systemic Burden cases involving the four categories identiﬁed above. The ﬁrst exception is for cases received from a Congressional Office, see TAS-13-0721-0008 , Interim Guidance on Accepting Cases Under TAS Case Criteria 9, Public Policy. The second exception is for cases related to other issues for which TAS may advocate, such as an open examination or collection action that a refund from, or the process- ing of, the amended or original return or claim would resolve. The following examples illustrate these guidelines:

There are two notable exceptions under which TAS will continue to accept Systemic Burden cases involving the four categories identiﬁed above. The ﬁrst exception is for cases received from a Congressional Office, see TAS-
, Interim Guidance on Accepting Cases Under TAS Case Criteria

, Public Policy. The second exception is for cases related to other issues for which TAS may advocate, such as an open examination or collection action that a refund from, or the process- ing of, the amended or original return or claim would resolve. The following examples illustrate these guidelines:

Facts: The normal processing time for a Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Indi- vidual Income Tax Return, is approximately eight to 12 weeks. The taxpayer ﬁled 2020 Form 1040-X more than four months ago expecting a refund and has no other outstanding issues with examination or collection. Because of the IRS delay in processing the amended return, the taxpay- er’s circumstances meet TAS Criteria 5. Under the new guidelines, refer the taxpayer to the appropriate IRS function for resolution and do not establish a TAS case.
Assume the same facts as in Example 1, except that the case has been referred by a congressional office. Establish a TAS case.

employees. However, TAS will continue accepting those cases involving the processing of original and amended returns that otherwise meet case accep- tance criteria. This guidance is summarized below:

If the inquiry Then Is received from a Congressional Office, including ERS Status 100 and 900 cases. TAS will accept the case. These cases will be coded in TAMIS as Criteria 9 even if they may also qualify under Criteria 1 through 8. Involves an Offset Bypass Refund (OBR). TAS will accept the case. See IRM 13.1.24.6.2, Advocating for Taxpayers Seeking Offset Bypass Refunds. Involves other issues, such as Collection, that are not dependent on receipt of the return before TAS can begin advocating on the taxpayer’s behalf. TAS will accept the case. Is received from any source, other than a Congressional Office, and involves a return that is not showing as received on IDRS. TAS will not accept the case. See IRM 21.4.1.4.1, Locating the Tax- payer’s Return. Is received from any source, other than a Congressional Office, and the return is in ERS status 100 or 900. TAS will not accept the case.
) As of May
, per TAS-
, Interim Guidance on Exceptions to TAS Case Acceptance Criteria For Taxpayer Issues Related to Unemployment Compensation Received in Taxable Year
, TAS will generally not accept cases involving the exclusion of unemployment compensation received in tax- able year
from gross income per IRC
(c). However, TAS will continue to accept those unemployment compensation cases that otherwise meet case acceptance criteria:

As of May 4, 2021, per TAS-13-0521-0006 , Interim Guidance on Exceptions to TAS Case Acceptance Criteria For Taxpayer Issues Related to Unemployment Compensation Received in Taxable Year 2020, TAS will generally not accept cases involving the exclusion of unemployment compensation received in tax- able year 2020 from gross income per IRC 85(c). However, TAS will continue to accept those unemployment compensation cases that otherwise meet case acceptance criteria:

If the Inquiry Then Involves identity theft where the taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS case acceptance criteria 1-4, 8 and 9. TAS will accept the case. Involves identity theft where the taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS case acceptance criteria 5-7. TAS will not accept the case, see paragraph (8) below.
) As of July
, per TAS-

, Interim Guidance - Advance Child Tax Credit, TAS will generally not accept stand-alone Advance Child Tax Credit (ACTC) cases. TAS cannot expedite resolution or improve assistance to tax- payers in these situations. However, TAS will accept ACTC cases that also in- volve other issues meeting normal TAS criteria for which TAS may advocate.

If the Inquiry Then Involves stand-alone ACTC issues including, but not limited to: • Unenrollment, • Use of the Non-Filer Sign-up Tool, • ACTC payment inquiries, or • IRS Online Account acces- sibility, such as IRS username, ID.me, etc. TAS will not accept the case. Involves unresolved account issues per IRM 21.6.3.4.1.24.2(9), Advance CTC, that meet TAS criteria and are postponing ACTC payments. TAS will accept the case. Involves ACTC and other issues meeting normal TAS criteria for which TAS may advocate. TAS will accept the case.
For any issue where TAS is not able to directly assist the taxpayer, TAS will:
Educate the taxpayer and direct them to any available IRS resources and provide the appropriate IRS toll

free number, if available; Use outreach and other forums to gather feedback and improve the IRS’s educational resources and Identify systemic problems using the Systemic Advocacy Management System (SAMS) and work with the IRS to correct them.
) The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act), created IRC
, which provides for a recovery rebate credit (RRC) for eligible indi- viduals. The CARES Act allows for the advanced payment of the RRC (referred to as Economic Impact Payments (EIP)) until December
Taxpayers will report the RRC on their tax year
tax return and reduce the credit by the EIP, if applicable. Refer to IRM
, Economic Impact Payments, for IRS guidance on identifying and resolving Economic Impact Payment (EIP) issues.

) Problems that meet TAS criteria do not necessarily need to be sent to TAS when an operating division or function can immediately resolve them. It is important that all IRS employees handle potential TAS cases with the taxpay- er’s best interest in mind. The deﬁnition of “Same Day Resolution” is “within hours”. The following two situations meet the deﬁnition of “Same Day Resolu- tion:” • The issue can be resolved within
hours. • The IRS takes steps within
hours to resolve the taxpayer’s issue.
Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria 13.1.7 page
Cases that can be resolved on the “Same Day” should not be referred to TAS unless the taxpayer makes the request. Before referring potential cases to TAS, the following guidelines will be applied:
a. A case meeting TAS criteria may be retained in the general program area when the problem has been corrected or will be resolved immediately (within
hours) to the taxpayer’s satisfaction, or resolution is under- taken (within
hours) AND b. The taxpayer is advised of the name, phone number, and unique identiﬁ- cation number of the employee who resolved the problem, AND c. The NTA toll-free number,
, is provided and the taxpayer is advised that TAS is available if the resolution is not satisfactory.

Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria 13.1.7 page

Term Deﬁnition Case Advocacy Any employee working to advocate for the taxpayer. (This could include Intakes, Case Advocates, TAGMs, LTAs, etc.). Economic Impact Payment (EIP) A recovery rebate credit for eligible individuals disbursed in ﬁscal year 2020. Offset Bypass Refund (OBR) Issuance of a manual refund without ﬁrst satisfying outstanding Federal tax liabilities when the taxpayer has an economic hardship. Operations Assistance Request (OAR) Refers to Form 12412 which TAS employees use to recommend or request that the IRS act to resolve an issue when TAS lacks the statutory or delegated authority to resolve a taxpayer’s problem. Pre-Refund Wage Veriﬁcation Hold (PRWVH) Refers to the revenue protection program managed by the Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Operation (RIVO) that identiﬁes returns reporting false or fraudulent income. TAMIS Computerized inventory control and report system used by TAS employees to assign, control, and maintain TAS inventory. Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO) A statutory tool used by TAS to order the IRS to take certain actions, cease certain actions, or refrain from taking certain actions. See IRC 7811 and IRM 13.1.20, TAS Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO) Process. TAS uses Form 9102 to issue a
A statutory tool used by TAS to order the IRS to take certain actions, cease certain actions, or refrain from taking certain actions. See IRC
and IRM
, TAS Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO) Process. TAS uses Form
to issue a TAO to the IRS.

Economic Burden 2 The taxpayer is facing an immediate threat of adverse action. 7811(a)(2)(A) 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii)(A); (iv) Example 1 Economic Burden 3 The taxpayer will incur signiﬁcant costs if relief is not granted (including fees for pro- fessionalrepresentation). 7811(a)(2)(C) 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii)(C); (iv) Example 3 Economic Burden 4 The taxpayer will suffer irreparable injury or long-term adverse impact if relief is not granted. 7811(a)(2)(D) 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii)(D); (iv) Example 4 Systemic Burden 5 The taxpayer has ex- perienced a delay of more than 30 days to resolve a tax account problem. 7811(a)(2)(B) 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii)(B)and(iii);(iv)Example2 Systemic Burden 6 The taxpayer has not received a response or resolution to the problem or inquiry by the date promised. 7811(a)(1)(B) -- Sec’y via Regs 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii);(iv)Example2 System Burden 7 A system or procedure has either failed to operate as intended, or failed to resolve the taxpayer’s problem or dispute within the IRS. 7811(a)(1)(B) -- Sec’y via Regs 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii) Best Interest of Taxpayer 8 The manner in which the tax laws are being administered raises considerations of equity, or has impaired or will impair the tax- payer’s rights. 7811(a)(1)(B) -- Sec’y via Regs 301.7811-1(a)(4)(ii) -- serious privation; TBOR
